history.content:
Anecdotally, I got a B+ in 188 and 127 too and thought it was all over for me but now am doing research in one of the labs you just listed :) I think passion matters more (believe me, professors see it) as well as previous research experience helped me out a lot (which is awesome because you have it!) Idk if this is very helpful but feel free to ask more questions!

-----------------------------------------------------------------

First things first, BAIR/Autolab/RAIL are not the only labs/lab groups doing awesome AI research work, there is much more value in the substance being appealing and relevant to you than the name prestige of a lab. The great gift of research is being able to contribute in a meaningful way to a substantive and meaningful project, far beyond any title or position.

With that said, to answer your specific question, you can absolutely make your way to one of those labs even with those "low" grades. While there are some faculty who put a primary emphasis on grades and how many A+s you have, there are many who are looking for demonstrated interest and a willingness to commit, which your previous research background already lends itself to. Having taken the relevant classes and doing well in them will always help, but in my experience, it has not been make-or-break.

I found my way into a BAIR lab after reaching out directly to one of the Ph.D. students working on a research project I was really interested in with a faculty sponsor (rather than reaching out to the faculty themselves, which I never found at all fruitful when it comes to getting a response). While your individual experience may definitely vary, my impression is that Ph.D. students expectedly tend to be much more aware of the day-to-day of the projects in their lab's project(s) and know whether or not there is a need for another researcher. If they feel that that is the case, they are generally happy to facilitate your introduction into the lab and connecting with the faculty member. However, some professors may prefer that you reach out to them directly, so keep that in mind.

Hope that helps. Good luck!

Anecdotally, I got a B+ in 188 and 127 too and thought it was all over for me but now am doing research in one of the labs you just listed :) I think passion matters more (believe me, professors see it) as well as previous research experience helped me out a lot (which is awesome because you have it!) children.subject: I suggest directly emailing them or showing up to office hours! And talk about your internship this summer too, relating it to their work if possible

@student answer not OP, but I was curious how one can approach professors/labs for research opportunities? The work I will be doing in my internship this summer is quite relevant to BAIR/Berkeley DeepDrive, but I feel my courseload isn't as strong as most people in those labs (only relevant upper div is 188, I took mostly systems upper divs so far). I am also interested in RISE lab, but again not sure how to approach. Thanks!

history.content: I'm looking for opportunities in BAIR/Autolab/RAIL (having past AI research for over a year in another STEM department.) However, due to a rough Fall 2020, I got a B+ in both EECS127 and CS188 which were my first upper division classes. Unfortunately, most professors in BAIR require an A/A+ in CS188 and other relevant courses such as 127. (I'm currently doing well in both EECS126 and CS170, and planning on taking CS189 next semester.) How can I possibly make up for bad grades in these classes to get research opportunities as soon as possible?
history.subject: Research advice after a rough semester
